title: Dyspraxia — Developmental Coordination Disorder
author: Marijke Vroomen Durning, RN

sections.heading: What Is Dyspraxia?
content: Dyspraxia is one of many neurodevelopmental disorders that affect how your neurological (nerve) system and brain function. Most people call it just dyspraxia, but the official diagnosis is developmental coordination disorder (DCD). You might also hear it called developmental dyspraxia. About 5%-6% of people in the U.S. have dyspraxia. That’s one in 20 people.
Dyspraxia was recognized as a true disorder in the late 1980s. Before that, people with the symptoms were said to have “Clumsy Child Syndrome.”
Dyspraxia in adults

Some people only find out they have dyspraxia when they’re adults. When they look back at their childhood, they might recognize symptoms that were either unnoticed or noticed but not diagnosed. However, dyspraxia in adults isn’t usually the same as it is in children. In children, dyspraxia (DCD) is a developmental disorder. In adults, the word is used more broadly. It can just mean you’re having trouble with things such as motor functions, working memory, organizing, and planning.
There is also acquired dyspraxia that can affect you as an adult. This can happen when your dyspraxia symptoms begin after you have a stroke or brain injury.

Dyspraxia is a condition that can affect many aspects of your child’s life, from fine motor issues (like getting dressed or writing) to gross motor functions (like walking, jumping, or balancing). There is no cure for it but early treatment could help your child adapt to having dyspraxia, lessening some symptoms. (Photo Credit: Brand X Pictures/Getty Images)

Most people call it just dyspraxia, but the official diagnosis is developmental coordination disorder (DCD). You might also hear it called developmental dyspraxia. About 5%-6% of people in the U.S. have dyspraxia. That’s one in 20 people.

Some people only find out they have dyspraxia when they’re adults. When they look back at their childhood, they might recognize symptoms that were either unnoticed or noticed but not diagnosed. However, dyspraxia in adults isn’t usually the same as it is in children. In children, dyspraxia (DCD) is a developmental disorder. In adults, the word is used more broadly. It can just mean you’re having trouble with things such as motor functions, working memory, organizing, and planning.

Dyspraxia is a condition that can affect many aspects of your child’s life, from fine motor issues (like getting dressed or writing) to gross motor functions (like walking, jumping, or balancing). There is no cure for it but early treatment could help your child adapt to having dyspraxia, lessening some symptoms. (Photo Credit: Brand X Pictures/Getty Images)

sections.heading: Dyspraxia vs. Apraxia
content: Dyspraxia and apraxia might be used by some people as if they’re the same condition, but there’s a difference. Dyspraxia means you have trouble or partial ability but you can still do at least some of the task. Apraxia means you can’t do the task at all.
Someone who is diagnosed with apraxia may have specific subtypes, such as childhood apraxia of speech.

content_blocks.text: Dyspraxia and apraxia might be used by some people as if they’re the same condition, but there’s a difference. Dyspraxia means you have trouble or partial ability but you can still do at least some of the task. Apraxia means you can’t do the task at all.
Someone who is diagnosed with apraxia may have specific subtypes, such as childhood apraxia of speech.

sections.heading: Dyspraxia Causes
content: Researchers haven’t found a direct cause for dyspraxia but there are theories. Some researchers believe that the neurological system doesn’t fully mature in people who have dyspraxia but they don’t know why. Other research shows that dyspraxia could be genetic or there might be psychological factors.
Who gets dyspraxia?
Anyone can have dyspraxia but it is diagnosed more often in boys than in girls. It’s about seven times more common among boys. Those who are more likely to have dyspraxia include children who:
bullets: Have family members who have dyspraxia
Were born weighing less than 4 pounds, which is considered a very low birth weight
Were born before the 37th week of pregnancy , with an even higher risk if they’re born before the 32nd week

sections.heading: Dyspraxia Symptoms
content: There are many symptoms of dyspraxia. The type and severity vary quite a bit.
Basic symptoms can include:
Dyspraxia symptoms in babies

Dyspraxia may not be easy to spot in babies because some of the symptoms could be caused by something else, or your baby might be just a bit behind on reaching milestones . That said, if your baby shows any of these symptoms, you should speak with your doctor to see if dyspraxia could be the cause:
Dyspraxia symptoms in kids

Not all children develop at the same rate and these symptoms don’t necessarily point to dyspraxia. However,  it would be a good idea to ask your doctor for an evaluation if your child is older and shows symptoms like these:
bullets: Difficulty with balance and coordination
Being clumsy
Vision problems
Emotional and behavioral problems
Difficulty with communication — reading, writing, speaking
Poor short-term memory
Poor posture
Poor social skills
Delay in rolling over, sitting, crawling, or walking
Holding their body in unusual positions up to their first birthday
Difficulty building with blocks or playing with toys that need some coordination
Difficulty learning how to use a spoon to eat
Not keeping up with their peers with activities such as jumping, running, or catching or kicking a ball
Having problems going up and down stairs
Having difficulty when trying to write (may be unable to write clearly), using scissors, or other tools
Not being able to dress themselves, doing buttons, zippers, and tying shoelaces
Moving unintentionally, such as waving about their arms and legs
Being clumsy, bumping into things, dropping what they’re holding, or falling
Difficulty keeping up in school because they can’t concentrate or follow instructions
Having poor organizational skills, like keeping up with homework
Being bullied or difficulty making friends
Having behavior problems, often out of frustration
Having low self-esteem

sections.heading: Dyspraxia symptoms in adults
content: Dyspraxia symptoms in adults may change over time, but if you have some of these symptoms, you may have the condition:
bullets: Difficulty with coordination, balance, and movement
Difficulty learning new skills
Poor memory
Poor time management, organization, and planning
Changes in your ability to dress yourself or perform other daily tasks, such as cooking
Changes in your writing
Changes in how you can use tools such as scissors
Challenges to function in social situations
Changes in your ability to handle or manage your emotions

content_blocks.text: Dyspraxia symptoms in adults may change over time, but if you have some of these symptoms, you may have the condition:

Changes in your writing
Changes in how you can use tools such as scissors
Challenges to function in social situations
Changes in your ability to handle or manage your emotions

sections.heading: Dyspraxia and writing
content: It might seem simple to be able to write, but handwriting needs a lot of effort. You have to organize your thoughts about what you want to write, use vocabulary and grammar, and then do the writing. This is why writing can be hard for people with dyspraxia.

People with dyspraxia also tend to write more slowly. They can have trouble writing clearly because it’s hard to form the letter shapes. This makes their handwriting look messy or sloppy. Up to 95% of children with dyspraxia have a hard time with their handwriting.

content_blocks.text: It might seem simple to be able to write, but handwriting needs a lot of effort. You have to organize your thoughts about what you want to write, use vocabulary and grammar, and then do the writing. This is why writing can be hard for people with dyspraxia.

People with dyspraxia also tend to write more slowly. They can have trouble writing clearly because it’s hard to form the letter shapes. This makes their handwriting look messy or sloppy. Up to 95% of children with dyspraxia have a hard time with their handwriting.

sections.heading: Dyspraxia Diagnosis
content: The official diagnosis of dyspraxia is developmental coordination disorder (DCD). The diagnosis isn’t typically made until a child starts school because many factors may lead to delays in reaching certain milestones or developmental stages. However, if the delays persist or become more noticeable, it’s important to have your child examined for dyspraxia.
You can get a diagnosis from different health care professionals, including a:

There aren’t any specific tests for dyspraxia, but your child might have tests to rule out medical conditions that could cause the symptoms. Otherwise, the health care professionals will look at your child’s medical history, as well as your description of their growth and development. They’ll also look at your child’s:
bullets: Pediatrician
Pediatric neurologist
Occupational therapist
Physical therapist
Child psychologist
Gross skills, such as walking and hopping, to see if they are at the level expected for this age
Fine motor skills, such as drawing, doing up buttons, or using a spoon to see if they affect their daily activities and ability to do tasks at school
Coordination
Balance
Mental ability

Coordination
Balance
Mental ability

sections.heading: Dyspraxia and autism
content: Autism spectrum disorder can have symptoms similar to those of dyspraxia. People with dyspraxia can also have autism spectrum disorder so symptoms can overlap. Autism is a related condition, but the two conditions aren’t the same.

Autism is a disorder that affects communication, behavior, interests, and activities. Many experts say that people with autism don’t have symptoms but rather characteristics, which are specific behaviors. Dyspraxia has physical symptoms, such as a lack of balance or difficulty using fine motor skills.

sections.heading: Dyspraxia Treatment
content: There’s no cure for dyspraxia, but there are some therapies that could help improve motor function, fine motor skills, and other problem issues.

Since people with dyspraxia have different symptoms and different severity, everyone needs an individual approach. Here are some therapies that might help people with dyspraxia manage their condition. The earlier treatment starts in childhood, the better the results might be.
Occupational therapy

Occupational therapy is likely central to your child’s treatment plan. If your child is having difficulty with activities such as eating, toileting, dressing, or even playing, an occupational therapist can work with them by providing necessary tools and teaching them coping skills. This could include teaching your child how to break down tasks into small steps or learning a task slowly step-by-step until it can be finished. Tools could include shoes with Velcro if tying laces is too hard, using a large, handled spoon if a regular handle is too slim to hold, or having your child type instead of writing by hand.

content_blocks.text: There’s no cure for dyspraxia, but there are some therapies that could help improve motor function, fine motor skills, and other problem issues.

Occupational therapy

Occupational therapy is likely central to your child’s treatment plan. If your child is having difficulty with activities such as eating, toileting, dressing, or even playing, an occupational therapist can work with them by providing necessary tools and teaching them coping skills. This could include teaching your child how to break down tasks into small steps or learning a task slowly step-by-step until it can be finished. Tools could include shoes with Velcro if tying laces is too hard, using a large, handled spoon if a regular handle is too slim to hold, or having your child type instead of writing by hand.

sections.heading: Physical therapy
content: A physical therapist can provide a plan to help improve body strength, which in turn can help with running, balance, and coordination. Exercises could include having your child:
Psychology

Many children with dyspraxia also struggle with emotional, psychological, and behavioral issues. Therapy with an educational psychologist can help give your child the tools they need to manage these issues.
bullets: Go through an obstacle course
Stand on one foot
Ride a bike
Playing catch
Swinging or rolling on the ground
Pretending to be an animal, crawling, creeping, etc.

content_blocks.text: A physical therapist can provide a plan to help improve body strength, which in turn can help with running, balance, and coordination. Exercises could include having your child:
associated_bullets: Go through an obstacle course
Stand on one foot
Ride a bike
Playing catch
Swinging or rolling on the ground
Pretending to be an animal, crawling, creeping, etc.

content_blocks.text: Psychology

Many children with dyspraxia also struggle with emotional, psychological, and behavioral issues. Therapy with an educational psychologist can help give your child the tools they need to manage these issues.

sections.heading: Living With Dyspraxia
content: Living with dyspraxia can be challenging, depending on how severely your child is affected. It’s important to ask for help when needed, such as getting therapy or school accommodations.
How to help your child with dyspraxia
You are your child’s best advocate. Here are some suggestions that might help you help your child deal with dyspraxia.
bullets: Let your child know that you’re there to help them.

Set them up to be as successful as possible. This could mean breaking down tasks so they’re more easily completed, helping them practice the same thing, and providing support for when they feel like they’ve failed.
Provide necessary tools, such as extra wide grips for pencils if holding a pencil is tough.
Follow up with exercises or tasks recommended by the occupational therapist or physical therapist.

content_blocks.text: Living with dyspraxia can be challenging, depending on how severely your child is affected. It’s important to ask for help when needed, such as getting therapy or school accommodations.
How to help your child with dyspraxia
You are your child’s best advocate. Here are some suggestions that might help you help your child deal with dyspraxia.

items: Let your child know that you’re there to help them.

Set them up to be as successful as possible. This could mean breaking down tasks so they’re more easily completed, helping them practice the same thing, and providing support for when they feel like they’ve failed.
Provide necessary tools, such as extra wide grips for pencils if holding a pencil is tough.
Follow up with exercises or tasks recommended by the occupational therapist or physical therapist.

sections.heading: Dyspraxia Treatment
content: There’s no cure for dyspraxia, but there are some therapies that could help improve motor function, fine motor skills, and other problem issues.

Since people with dyspraxia have different symptoms and different severity, everyone needs an individual approach. Here are some therapies that might help people with dyspraxia manage their condition. The earlier treatment starts in childhood, the better the results might be.
Occupational therapy

Occupational therapy is likely central to your child’s treatment plan. If your child is having difficulty with activities such as eating, toileting, dressing, or even playing, an occupational therapist can work with them by providing necessary tools and teaching them coping skills. This could include teaching your child how to break down tasks into small steps or learning a task slowly step-by-step until it can be finished. Tools could include shoes with Velcro if tying laces is too hard, using a large, handled spoon if a regular handle is too slim to hold, or having your child type instead of writing by hand.

Occupational therapy

Occupational therapy is likely central to your child’s treatment plan. If your child is having difficulty with activities such as eating, toileting, dressing, or even playing, an occupational therapist can work with them by providing necessary tools and teaching them coping skills. This could include teaching your child how to break down tasks into small steps or learning a task slowly step-by-step until it can be finished. Tools could include shoes with Velcro if tying laces is too hard, using a large, handled spoon if a regular handle is too slim to hold, or having your child type instead of writing by hand.

content: A physical therapist can provide a plan to help improve body strength, which in turn can help with running, balance, and coordination. Exercises could include having your child:
Psychology

Many children with dyspraxia also struggle with emotional, psychological, and behavioral issues. Therapy with an educational psychologist can help give your child the tools they need to manage these issues.
bullets: Go through an obstacle course
Stand on one foot
Ride a bike
Playing catch
Swinging or rolling on the ground
Pretending to be an animal, crawling, creeping, etc.

associated_bullets: Go through an obstacle course
Stand on one foot
Ride a bike
Playing catch
Swinging or rolling on the ground
Pretending to be an animal, crawling, creeping, etc.

content_blocks.text: Psychology

Many children with dyspraxia also struggle with emotional, psychological, and behavioral issues. Therapy with an educational psychologist can help give your child the tools they need to manage these issues.

How to help your child with dyspraxia
You are your child’s best advocate. Here are some suggestions that might help you help your child deal with dyspraxia.
bullets: Let your child know that you’re there to help them.

Set them up to be as successful as possible. This could mean breaking down tasks so they’re more easily completed, helping them practice the same thing, and providing support for when they feel like they’ve failed.

Follow up with exercises or tasks recommended by the occupational therapist or physical therapist.

content: When it comes to your child’s education, working closely with the school is important. Contact your child’s school about setting up an Individualized Education Plan (IEP) if your child qualifies. An IEP is a personalized plan to address your child’s educational needs, and public schools are required to provide them to students who qualify. To start, your child is evaluated to see where services or support is needed and then the plan is made. These plans are updated regularly to monitor how well they are working, if your child needs more help, or if the help is no longer needed.
Speaking to the teacher is also important because they can set up ways for your child to succeed in the classroom, like:
If you’re an adult with dyspraxia, you can ask at work if they can make accommodations as well, similar to what a school can do for students.
bullets: Allowing your child extra time to complete assignments
Allowing your child to type instead of writing out assignments
Breaking assignments into smaller chunks
Encouraging a student buddy to help your child with taking notes
Allowing your child to take notes with a computer
Providing a quiet spot where your child can take small breaks when things get too overwhelming

sections.heading: Dyspraxia Complications
content: Dyspraxia doesn't come with the same complications as diseases like diabetes, but having dyspraxia can cause other issues. This could include having difficulty managing behavior, completing tasks, or doing things that many people take for granted, such as dressing quickly or eating without spilling.
Other issues someone with dyspraxia may experience include:
bullets: Difficulties at home and work because of problems with remembering information or learning new skills
Isolation due to difficulty with social situations, dealing with emotions
Fatigue, because of the extra effort it takes, both emotionally and physically, to complete tasks
Getting injured easily because of frequent bumps or falls
Emotional distress and depression

Emotional distress and depression

sections.heading: Dyspraxia Prevention
content: Since researchers don’t know what causes dyspraxia, no one knows if there’s a way to prevent it. While good prenatal care that helps reduce the risk of having a premature delivery or a baby with a low birth weight may lower the risk, even children who were delivered at full term at a healthy weight can have the condition.

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: Dyspraxia’s official name is developmental coordination disorder, and it can affect many aspects of your child’s life, from fine motor issues (difficulty getting dressed or writing) to gross motor functions (like walking, jumping, and keeping balance). It can even affect how your child behaves. There is no cure for it, but early intervention could help your child adapt to having dyslexia, making the symptoms less pronounced. School accommodations are also important to help children reach their potential.

content_blocks.text: Dyspraxia’s official name is developmental coordination disorder, and it can affect many aspects of your child’s life, from fine motor issues (difficulty getting dressed or writing) to gross motor functions (like walking, jumping, and keeping balance). It can even affect how your child behaves. There is no cure for it, but early intervention could help your child adapt to having dyslexia, making the symptoms less pronounced. School accommodations are also important to help children reach their potential.

sections.heading: Dyspraxia FAQs
content: What does dyspraxia look like?

Dyspraxia doesn’t have a specific set of symptoms, but it can affect people in many different ways. Some people with dyspraxia seem very uncoordinated, falling and bumping into things frequently. Other people have difficulty with fine motor skills, making it difficult to do tasks such as tying shoelaces, doing up buttons, or writing with a pen.
What triggers dyspraxia?
There is no trigger for dyspraxia. Doctors don’t know what causes it.
Is dyspraxia a form of autism?

content_blocks.text: What does dyspraxia look like?

Dyspraxia doesn’t have a specific set of symptoms, but it can affect people in many different ways. Some people with dyspraxia seem very uncoordinated, falling and bumping into things frequently. Other people have difficulty with fine motor skills, making it difficult to do tasks such as tying shoelaces, doing up buttons, or writing with a pen.
What triggers dyspraxia?
There is no trigger for dyspraxia. Doctors don’t know what causes it.
Is dyspraxia a form of autism?

content: Dyspraxia and autism are not the same condition. Dyspraxia has symptoms, such as having difficulty keeping balance, doing fine motor skill tasks, or controlling behavior. Autism, on the other hand, has characteristics, such as repetitive behavior, difficulty communicating, and having problems with social interactions.
What are the personality traits of a dyspraxia person?
Dyspraxia appears differently in different people so there are no specific personality traits related to having the condition.
What is the most common illness that dyspraxia is linked to?

Many people with dyspraxia also have other conditions, such as attention deficit hyperactive disorder ( adhd ), dyslexia , autism spectrum disorder, dyscalculia , depression , or anxiety. There isn’t a most common one though.

meta_description: Dyspraxia is a developmental disorder affecting coordination and motor skills, leading to difficulty with tasks like writing, balance, and planning movements.
